description.title: Every Datapoint a Person
description.subtitle: Description of a Slave Ship
description.description: Before there are data, there are people. People who offer up their lives as data — or whose lives become data without consent.

dubois.title: Between Data and Truth
dubois.subtitle: W.E.B. Du Bois's “Data Portraits”
dubois.description: How can data visualization bear witness to oppression? How can we hold space for what cannot be conveyed through data alone?

labor.title: From Idea to Insight
labor.subtitle: The Making of Data by Design
labor.description: Any digital project is the work of many hands. How can this labor be visualized? What remains out of sight?

peabody.title: The Work of Knowledge
peabody.subtitle: Elizabeth Palmer Peabody's Chronological Grids
peabody.description: We have explored only part of the history of data visualization. What possibilities can we imagine when we expand our view of the past?

playfair.title: What Visualization Reveals
playfair.subtitle: William Playfair's Time-Series Charts
playfair.description: Data visualization has never been neutral or objective. There is a meaning — and an argument — conveyed through each visual design.

shanawdithit.title: The Power of the Frame
shanawdithit.subtitle: Shanawdithit's Thematic Maps
shanawdithit.description: Maps can represent reality and can contest it. How can we learn to see the lines of power that they encode?
